text: A small country town. Normally quiet at this hour, the street is tonight alive with trick or treaters dressed as witches, goblins and superheroes making their annual door door rounds.
GLADYS PERRY, 30 going on 45 due to single motherhood and having worked two fulltime minimum wage jobs the past ten years, looks out the window with disgust and pulls the curtains closed.

Gladys retreats   from the sparsly decorated living room predictably drab   linoleum kitchen. At the table, hands their laps, sit   her children, NAOMI and RUTH, twin girl 10, and PHILLIP,   a quiet boy of 8.
Gladys sets a casserole on the table and goes to the frig a container of milk. The children WHISPER to one another.
Judy Baumer is going as a twirler.
But she's so fat.     I'd go as Cinderella... or Peter Pan.
Peter Pan's a boy. Tinker Bell's a girl. Phillip could go as Peter Pan... 'cept you gotta' fly. Phillip smiles a bit at the notion.
Phillip could go as a bump on a log. The girls giggle and Phillip frowns.
Why can't we go just once?
Caus' we jus' can't, ok? Gladys sets milk and butter on the table and stares direc at her son.
Our personal beliefs lift us to a higher place. 'Sides, Halloween is nothing but the Devil's work. The DOORBELL RINGS.   The kids gulp as Gladys turns and h for the door.
MR. HUGHES, a 35-year-old family man is playing chaperone prepubescent versions of SUPERMAN, TINKERBELL, and a DANC SKELETON.
(in unison)
Trick or treat!!! Gladys simply stares at the children before looking to Mr Hughes.
I'm sorry but we don't take no part in Halloween.
Excuse me? Phillip arrives at his mother's apron. He stares at the k with relish. In the near window, Ruth and Naomi steal a l through the window.
We're Jehovah's Witness. Superman locks eyes with Phillip.
Hey, Phillip Perry.
Hey, Billy Reeves.
How'd ya' know it was me?
Go eat your supper, Phillip.
Come on, kids. Let's go to the next house. Sorry for the bother. Gladys closes the door firmly and locks it.
A green Impala pulls up to the main entrance and stops. A GUARD steps from his office to greet the driver, LARRY, a pudgy 55-year-old prison employee wearing a loud plaid ja
Evenin', Larry.   Forget somethin'?
Goin' to Austin tomorrow.      Gonna' take some work with me.
Work, work, work. When you and me gonna' go out and grab a cold one?
Sooner the better. The gate opens and the Impala passes.

BUTCH HAYNES, a 38-year-old inmate who reeks with knowled procured from the wrong side of the tracks, but whose sad tired eyes bemoan a maximum of regret, stands on the top cell bunk chipping at the ceiling. JERRY PUGH, 29, rail thin, a punk who constantly licks hi lips, keeps watch at the door. An OLD TIMER sits on his b and watches both with a cautious eye. Butch chips through to something.
Damn if the old man ain't right. Jerry smiles, turns and grabs the old man by the shirt.
And this goes to the roof?
Used to... afore they walled it over.
If it don't I'm gonna' rip your tongue out.
Get yer' damn hands off me! Jerry laughs and joins Butch, who is already well on his to bending open a slot in a corrugated metal air shaft hi behind the wall.
Superman and Dancing Skeleton, no longer with adult super vision, fill water balloons at an outdoor water spigot.
Make 'em small so you can heave 'em.

An assembly line at the kitchen sink as the twins wash an Phillip dries the evening dishes. Gladys sits at the kitc table, reading religious pamphlets and keeping a watchful over the process. Several THUDS resound through the house.
What in the world? Phillip jumps down off his stool and races into the livin room.
Superman lofts a BALLOON and grabs another as the first h the door of the Perry house and SPLATTERS.
Bombs away! Dancing Skeleton does his best Warren Spahn and tosses a fastball at the door.

Here's your trick! At the window, Phillip, his nose pressed to the pane, sta expressionless at the onslaught. He barely flinches as a BALLOON SPLATS only inches away. Gladys arrives and pulls the curtains shut once more.

Butch kicks the top off a ventilator shaft and rolls onto roof. Jerry follows as Butch shimmies to the wall. At the edge, Butch and Jerry survey the yard as a searchl routinely bathes the walls in a circle of light.
parked almost directly below them, next to the Administra office of the prison.
You'n'me must be livin' right, Butchie boy!
Let's get something straight. I don't like you. As soon as we're on our way, that's it.
Who said I liked you? Butch slides down and hangs from the ledge before droppin the roof of the building below.
A SOFT THUD causes a Guard to look up, but only momentari he spots Larry departing, files in hand, waving goodbye.
Have a safe trip now, Larry.

Just as Larry reaches the Impala, Butch and Jerry leap do and land on him. The spotlight showers them in a flash of light as it passes by. Butch cups his hand over Larry's mouth while Jerry reache into his jacket -- Bingo -- a shiny .38.
(to Larry)
Keep yer' mouth shut.
(to Larry)
Gawd I'd love to blow yer' head off.
Larry, driving with his eyes straight ahead, stops at the and waves a palm at the Guard, who opens without hesitati
'Night, Larry.
stuffed and hidden half on the floor and half under the m are Jerry and Butch.
'Night, Larry.
A weathered finger drops a quarter in a jukebox.
B-5.   Haven't heard that one in awhile. The woman, MAE, 45, a dog-tired waitress, punches in the numbers and returns to her post behind the counter. A lonesome HANK WILLIAMS tune pours forth.
Not since last night.     How's the pie? RED GARNETT, 60, a grizzled but handsome Texas Ranger, si at the counter slowly chewing.
Kinda rubbery.   It was better yesterday.
Same pie as yesterday. Not much call for rhubarb. Sell one slice a day. In the background we hear a SIREN. Red turns and watches police patrol car whiz past, lights on.
Yer off duty. Tell me, if I stopped bakin' 'em would you still come by every night? Red, preoccupied, takes another rubbery bite.
I don't know. Mae smiles and turns her back to Red as she cleans the gr
Naw, Red Garnett, you don't come in here for the coffee and pie. You come in here for the company. To see me. Another patrol car races past.   Red's eyes follow it.

Now that I've said that, I'll go   one better. What say I cook you dinner at my   place sometime? Steaks, baked taters,    cold beer, the works. Well?... I'm askin'    you out. She turns to face Red but he's gone. A coupla dollars lie next to the half-eaten pie. All she can do is sigh.

Red pulls up in front of a small house in a residential section of town. Police cars are everywhere and several officers are behind their vehicles, guns pointed at the h Red steps out of the car and is greeted by a POLICE SERGE about the same age as Red.
Long time, no see. What are you doin' here, Chief?
Couldn't sleep.   Whattaya got?
They walk. Red arrives at a truck with a 10 gallon coffee urn roped to the tailgate. He grabs a paper cup and pours

Guy holdin' his family hostage. She kicked him out, served him divorce papers, he came back drunk and pulled a .38. Fired two shots but we don't think anybody's hit. Actually you might know the guy from your sheriff days. Hayden Webb. Been on suspension for awhile. Ring any bells?
Yeah.   Lemme talk to him.
No can do.   Police jurisdiction. Red tastes the coffee -- cold. He spits it out, pours the contents of the cup on the ground and walks toward the fr yard. Sergeant follows.
And how are you guys doin'?
We got specific rules to follow in these kinda situations, Red. (gives in)
He won't talk. Jus' keeps yellin', crying and waving his gun around. Red moves forward into the yard.
At least use the megaphone, you stubborn jackass! But Red ignores and arrives at the front door.   He knock
Hayden, this is Red Garnett. We worked together a few years back. Mind if I come in? The YELLING inside STOPS and the door opens a crack.   HA 35, distraught, peers out.
'Evenin', Chief.
Leave it to the P.D. They got a three- ring circus out there and not one cup of hot coffee. You mind? Hayden mulls it over, then opens the door.

On the couch sits Hayden's wife, JULIE, cradling her two an infant and an 8-year-old boy. Julie sobs. Her eye and temple are bruised purple. Red slowly enters, nods to Julie, takes off his hat and s it on a lampstand. Hayden has moved away from Red against the wall. He holds the gun out at no one in particular.
Julie, put a pot of coffee on. She slowly gets up and moves to the kitchen, still weepin
Appreciate it.   Jus' what is it you want, Hayden?
I dunno... I want my job.    I want my family.
What'd they suspend you for?

I answer a call in South Austin. Girl gettin' raped, that's the word. I bust in the door, this lowlife is beatin' the shit outta her with a tire iron. 'Help me, help me,' she says. I take the guy down. He bites me. I break his arm. Case closed, right? No. She was his wife and they both sue me and the department. The guy's about to kill her and she sues me 'cause now he can't pump gas. They have chump change in the bank but they got the best lawyer in town. Three months I'm goin' crazy. No pay. Then my wife leaves me and I get served divorce papers by John Reese -- a sheriff's man. You know how embarrassin' that is? What's happenin', Chief? I mean, everybody's got a fuckin' lawyer! Julie emerges from the kitchen and retakes her seat.
You love her?    Love the kids?
Yeah.
Then why do you hit me! Hayden grips the quivering revolver tight and points it at her. Red calms the situation...
You don't wanna shoot her.
I swear to God I think I do.
Naw, Hayden, I don't     think so. I think you love her. You know      what else I think? That you'd like a way out     of this whole mess... That's where I come     in.
Sergeant and other cops stand around and watch the house.
Well, I'll be damned.
The front door opens and Julie emerges with her two kids. She takes a few cautious steps, then runs to the police.
Red sits on the coffee table, unloading Hayden's gun. opens the cylinder and drops the shells to the floor. A calmer Hayden exits the kitchen with Red's coffee. accepts it, takes a sip.
Hits the spot. Hayden starts to sob a bit.      Red hands over a handker which Hayden accepts.
No cuffs, huh, Chief?
Okay.   You ready? Hayden nods, they stand. Red picks up his hat, sticks it on his head, opens the door and holds it for... Hayden, transfixed by the multitude of lights outside. gulps.
We'll walk out together, okay? Hayden steps back, looks at Red, then reaches behind his back, underneath his shirt and pulls out a .22 pistol.
Any good officer has a back-up. Red holds his palms out and takes a step toward Hayden.
Lemme have it, Hayden. Hayden points the gun at Red, freezing him.
Was I a good officer, Chief? Red nods.
Was I a good deputy? The kinda man you could depend on to do what's right?
Yeah. Hayden smiles.
Thank you. Then he turns the GUN on himself, swallows the barrel and BLOWS his brains out.

Hayden's dead, covered body is carried out the door.    J screams and sobs, still holding her crying children. Red, looking pretty shook up, slowly exits the house. He stops and looks at Julie and the kids. His eyes lock with the little boy's.
Got a call, Chief Garnett.   They're lookin' for ya downtown. Red slowly walks away.   The little boy's eyes follow him
It's a small town version of a 7-11, kept open by an owne anxious to cash in on the later night munchies of beer drinkers. Good idea. Bad luck.

Jerry skims through a girly magazine, turning the pages w the gun. Butch, wearing Larry's plaid jacket, jimmies open the cas register. He looks to the floor then to... Jerry, who catches Butch's gaze, holds it, looks down at floor, then, smiling, looks back to Butch. He returns to the skin mag. Butch holds his stare at Jerry then, in one move, grabs a of cash and hops over the counter and out of the store. Jerry notices Butch leaving, grabs a handful of assorted Brach's candies and hurries after.
Hey, wait up! Jerry's feet scurry through a pool of blood and past a quivering hand.

It's very late, after midnight, and only a handful of peo half of whom are cleanup crews, shuffle through the offic A light from an office at the end of the hall catches our eye. A MUFFLED  VOICE over the phone...
I understan' your concern, Johnny.

Red, behind a huge    ranchstyle desk covered with files paper, sips coffee    with one hand, works a buffalo nick through magician's    paces with the other and balances t phone receiver in    the crook of his neck.
(on phone)

Cons are creatures o' habit. Like old coyotes, they'll crawl back into familiar holes. Uh huh... Yeah... Sure yer' right. Listen you go back to bed and I'll call you in the A.M. with an update. I'll have the files by then. Say hullo to the Mrs.. Red sighs, puts the PHONE back in the hook and stares at it until it RINGS again.
The CLANGING wind up alarm CLOCK reads 5:30 and Gladys op her eyes and gently quiets it with a touch. She groans an rises, not happy but used to the daily ritual required of
As the kitchen light comes on we see that the couch has b opened up to a bed in which all three children sleep. The twins sleep soundly but Phillip tosses and turns away fro the light.
The Impala creeps through the previously seen neighborhoo without its lights.
Butch drives while Jerry scours the block.
There's a Buick.
Don't want a Buick. Want a Ford.
Ford's leak oil.     A car's a car. Butch puts on the brakes and brings the car to a stop.
Then take the Buick.
Soon as we cross state line I'll do just that. (beat)

I'm tired of riding around. I'll check down the block... for a Ford! Jerry gets out, slams the door, lights a cigarette and wa away. Butch waits a few seconds, quietly turns the key one notc and checks the gas ggauge. It reads almost empty. He taps it with his finger but it doesn't budge. He sighs, looks and sees...
as he checks one locked car, then feeling eyes on his bac turns, looks at Butch, grins and disappears around a corn BUTCH discreetly exits the car himself, carefully closing door without a sound.
Gladys steps into a slip and snaps her bra while cracking into a skillet. By rote she salts, stirs, and pops bread the toaster.

FROM BEHIND a fence, THROUGH the opened, screened windows see Gladys at work. Phillip enters, dressed in cotton briefs and a T-shirt, d a chair from the kitchen table by the window and assists mother by buttering the toast. POV MOVES CLOSER.
Thank you, Phillip. Go wake up your sisters. Phillip dutifully steps down and returns to the living ro Gladys works to adjust her slip, then grabs plates and silverware and takes them to the table.
I take mine fried.

Gladys gasps at Jerry's face pressed against the screen, controls herself when he brandishes the pistol. He motion for her to open the back door. She does. He slides into t room and sits down at the table.
A Ford sits in a driveway. In the far b.g. a back porch l glares. Butch ENTERS FRAME, looks at the light, turns to Ford and starts to jimmie the lock. No luck. He rises and looks to the light.
Jerry stuffs a piece of toast in his mouth, grins at Glad and makes a motion to the counter.

A lil' on the bland side.   Gimme' that ketchup. She picks up a bottle of Heinz and inches toward him. Whe she gets close, he grabs her and forces her onto his lap. holds the gun to her throat and whispers in her ear.
Don't got a man around here, do ya'?
MR. CUMMINGS, 70, puts on his glasses and peers through t window.
Gladys sits on Jerry's lap, thanks to .38 caliber coercio The convict's hands move freely over the frightened woman body.
Feed me, sweet thing. Her shaking hands raise a forkful of eggs to his lips. licks them once then gobbles with gusto. Phillip enters the room and stops dead in his tracks.

Well lookie here, you do got a man! Jerry smiles at Phillip while he kisses and licks Glady's At once, Phillip darts across the room at Jerry, who back the boy with his gunhand, sending Phillip sprawling. Butch blasts through the door in an instant. With a swift kick to the head, Jerry is knocked senseless onto the flo against the cabinets. The gun slides across the floor and lands at Phillip's fe
(holding his ear)
I'm bleedin'! You happy? Butch gives Jerry an icy stare and kneels down to eye lev with Phillip. Butch looks at the gun and then at Phillip.
What's your name, boy?
(scared shitless)
Ph...   Phillip...
Well, okay Phillip. Reach down and pick up that pistola.
Give it to me.
(to Jerry)
Shut yer' mouth. (to Phillip)
Pick it up and bring it over here.
Phillip reaches down and slowly picks up the gun by the h He takes one step toward Butch, then another. Gladys, petrified, sobs. Phillip arrives armslength from Butch.
Now say 'stick 'em up.'
(hesitant)
Stick 'em up... Butch laughs and then a NOISE from outside brings him bac to reality. He grabs the gun and spins to see...
Standing outside the screen door, gun leveled. Before the man can utter a syllable, Butch grabs Phillip and points gun straight at Cummings. Jerry jumps up and grabs Gladys
Put the gun down, old timer. You couldn't hit me anyway. Probably shoot the boy. The PHONE RINGS.
Leave it be. The twins wiping sleep from their eyes, wander into the r
Mama?...
It's all right, honey. PHONE continues to RING. Cummings can't decide what to do with the gun he's pointing at Butch.
You deaf?!!!
Set it on the ground. Cummings reluctantly obeys.
We gotta' get the hell outta'here!
PHONE still RINGS...
Shut up! In one fluid move he rips the phone from the wall.    The silence is deafening.
(re: Gladys)
I vote we bring her with us.
No.
How we gonna' get outta' here without a hostage, tell me that? The whole goddam neighborhood's awake.
We'll take the boy. Silence.   Gladys can't believe her ears.   Then...

Nooooo!!! Jerry tosses Gladys aside. She collapses onto the floor. The TWINS instantly start to CRY. Phillip winds up and hits Butch as hard as he can. Butch him up, directs Cummings into the kitchen with the gun an for Jerry to lead.
You'll get him back. I swear it.
Butch, carrying Phillip, and Jerry emerge from the back o the house and race back to the Impala.

Phillip!!!!... Butch flips Jerry the gun, tosses Phillip into the passen seat, leaps over the hood and into the driver's seat. The CAR STARTS and SQUEALS away. Neighbors, aroused by the noise, exit their homes clad in robes, nighties and curlers.
Jerry FIRES a SHOT over their heads, sending them to the or scurrying for safety.
Ain't you folks ever heard of sleepin' in?!!

Cummings races from behind the house with the SHOTGUN, levels it and FIRES a BLAST... A nearby station wagon WINDOW SHATTERS. Rising from their cover position, its owners look at Cummings with disgust.
Nice shootin', Fred.

Garnett, still in the same clothes, rests the phone recei in his ear while he shuffles through the files before him Red's deputy and boy friday, TOM ADLER, 40, lank, thinnin hair, with a face as soft as Red's is hard, warms up Red' coffee with a jolt from the Chief's favorite plaid Thermo
(into phone)
Yes, Johnny, I do understand that... The jabbering on the other end of the phone line continue as Red's eyes squint to read the files.
The first is Jerry's, complete with a grinning mug shot i upper right hand corner. There are several pages in the f but Red's fingers quickly peruse the top rap sheet before turning to...
It's Butch's and again Red's fingers start to move down t page then they stop and move to the photo of Butch at the of the page.
A hint of recognition.    The jabbering continues...
A little younger than now.    A younger con with the grim of a man facing hard time.
keeps staring at the photo, oblivious to the phone conver tion he's "not having".
Red?     Red, you there?
(a whisper)
(to Adler)
Huh?
(a whisper)
He's talkin' to ya'.
Have you heard a word I've said?! Red comes to...
(into phone)
Yeah, Johnny. Jus' thinkin' is all....
(another whisper)

Press has been waiting almost an hour, Red. Red nods then notices someone at the door and motions her in... SALLY GERBER, 28, cute in a plain, no nonsense way, with giant curls accenting her round face in step with th latest hair fashions, enters the room, closes the door be her. She's nervous as hell but trying to hide it. Red motions her to have a seat while he finishes his call
(into phone)
Yeah.... Clear as a bell... Mi' sabe. Red hangs up the phone, takes a draw on the coffee mug an looks again at the file. He seems lost in time.
What'd he say?
(distracted)
Who?
The Guvner', Red. Red closes the file.
Reminded me it's an election year. Red turns his attention to Sally.
You drink before noon?
(confused)
Uh... no.
Good.     Last one I had was on a liquid diet.
Last what?
Secretary.
(remembering)
Penny Munroe.
I believe you have me confused. I'm here from Huntsville. Assigned by Governor Connally. Red is confused.     He turns a blank expression to Adler
Adler...    what is this? Adler searches the messy desk for something.
Rings a bell, Red. Believ' they sent us something about her this mornin'...
Who sent?...
... Guvner', Red. Adler finds the telex message sheet he's looking for and it to Red.
... Here it is.
(introducing)

Uh, I'm Sally Gerber. Criminologist with the State Prison System. Sally offers her hand. Red, perusing the telex, ignores b Adler shakes somewhat reluctantly, not sure if he's suppo to like her or not.
Tom Adler.   Deputy. State Police... System.
It's a relatively new procedure but I was assigned by Governor Connally...
(reading from telex)
... 'to work with State law enforcement officials in all affairs where penal matters coincide with those of the State Police.' It don't say nuthin' about...
... It includes parole and work release programs as well as penal escape situations. The office PHONE BUZZES.    Adler picks it up.
(into phone)
On our way, Marge. Adler hangs up the phone.

Gettin' antsy, Red. You scheduled it. Adler hangs up, grabs Red's tie and coat from a brass run the wall and hands them over. Red puts down the telex, st at Sally and reluctantly attempts to make himself present

The idea is that an understanding of the particular behavioral case histories should, in parole situations, help the subject to avoid habitual traps and, in penal escape situations could, conversely, identify those self-same traps as an aide to apprehension.

Adler stares at Sally then turns to Red with a "never hea the like" look of amazement on his face. Red, roguishly handsome in his tan, western cut blazer, c on tie and ten gallon hat, makes his way to the door. But before he exits...
In the first place, Miss Gerber.
Sally, please.
In the first place, Sally, it ain't a 'penal escape situation.' It's a manhunt. Fancy words in a circle don't help much.
And what does?
A nose like a Blue Tick, a medulla with an antenna and one helluva lot of coffee. And with that he's out the door.
A throng of photogs and news writers stuff the undersized room. The clamor settles when Red enters and steps behind the lectern.

Listen up, I'll only say it once. At approximately ten o'clock last night two inmates over to Huntsville, Robert 'Butch' Haynes and Jerry David Pugh, escaped through an air shaft, grabbed a prison employee's car and got out through the main gate. At approximately 1 A.M. we believe they robbed a market outside of Cut-n-Shoot and killed the store's owner.
Is the prison employee with them?
Was when they left the prison. Sally and Adler enter the room and stand beside the lecte observing. Red notices them.
What's the rap sheet on these guys like?
Long as Christmas eve to a kid. Haynes was doin' 40 for armed robbery and Pugh was ridin' 20 hisself for manslaughter and assorted parole vios.
Is there any indication of...
... Lemme' finish, Billy. This mornin' another hostage was taken... from a private home in Madisonville. A boy, age 8. Grabbed him out of bed.
Any sex offenses on Haynes or Pugh?
Yer' askin' if they're preverts.   Well, one is.
You got inter-agency cooperation on this?
Texas Rangers as the criminal investigation arm of the D.P.S. share responsibility with the F.B.I. due to the kid being taken. But I doubt they're out of bed yet. A few chuckles.
Red, how do you plan to apprehend the escapees?
Officially I can only say we have a full manhunt team on their trail and we'll proceed with due haste.
And unofficially? Red hesitates a moment, something's bothering him, then b out...
Unoffically? I'm gonna' hunt 'em like the rabid dogs they are.
Every hand in the place shoots up and Ad Lib questions fl like bullets.

That's all I've got but I'd like to introduce ya' to Miss Sally Gerber. She's straight from the Governor's office. Knows all about psychological profiles and the like. You probably have some questions for her. Red steps back and to one side. Sally is taken aback but warms to the idea and steps to the podium for her first p conference, ready to take on the tough questions, to show a bit, but.... There are no questions. In fact there is utter silence as every raised hand drops. Eyes stare. Red sighs and starts to walk away.

Look, fellas, I got work to do. And he heads out the door, followed by Sally's eyes and e reporter's in the room, who commence once again to yell o questions and mob after the Chief. Every reporter, that i except one. He's near the back of the room and he smiles and raises h hand. Sally, unsure what to do, looks to him...
You have a question?
Yes I do. Sally smiles a bit then puts on her serious face awaiting
You doin' anything tonight? Sally, steamed, glares at the guy and stomps out of the room.
I'm serious!
Butch is driving with Phillip in the front seat beside hi still in his underwear. Jerry, in the backseat, leers at Butch, aims out the window and FIRES ONCE.
An aluminum water tank spews a violent leak.

We got a handful of caps and yer' shootin' water tanks. He's a smart guy, huh, Phillip? Phillip doesn't move or change expression. Jerry smiles, almost to himself, and FIRES TWICE more for the hell of i The ROOF of the Impala EXPLODES with two holes as the car speeds off down the highway.
Red is finishing up with several reporters near the door the parking lot. Adler jumps in, holds up his hands.

All right, that's it, boys.   Chief's got work to do. Red and Adler move through the parking lot to SAUNDERS, 5 aide to the Governor. Saunder's seconds are a PHOTOGRAPHE young and energetic, and SUTTLE, 35, dark-haired, with a cowlick. Saunders shakes Red's hand and they turn to gaze upon...
parked in the middle of the lot hitched to the back of a Chevy truck. The Airstream is painted in state colors and sports banners, decals and logos.
Saunders follows Red as he walks around the showpiece, occasionally kicking a tire or two.
So whattaya' think? Saunders motions for the Photographer to come closer and pictures. He moves in next to Red and poses as the camera clicks.
We are very proud of this baby. Governor Connally special ordered it so state officials and dignitaries can ride in the parade in Dallas. You know President Kennedy's comin'?
So I hear.

Latest technology, oversized engine, complete kitchen and sleeping quarters, gun racks, frig, stove, the works. Even got a hot line phone straight to the Governor's office. Red stops circling and nods to Adler, who scurries away.
Fine piece of machinery.

What's more, as soon as it gets back from Dallas it will be at your requisitioned disposal. Perfect for lots of situations -- a headquarters on wheels. Red smiles, walks up to one of the Lone Star decals and r it off.
We'll take it.

Uh, Chief?.... Red rips off another decal. Adler and a few others start load equipment, guns and files into the motor home. In addition they cart out unecessary items: mattresses, etc. and stack them in a pile outside the motor home. The Photographer continues to snap photos.
(to Red)
Whattaya' doin', Red?! (to Photographer)
Stop takin' pictures! Red does away with the parade banner.   Saunders follows and tries to reinstate the decal.
It's jus' not possible, Red. The Governor's gonna' ride it in a campaign parade tomorrow.
Guvner' hisself told me this manhunt was top priority.
Adler moves through the door to the RV carrying Red's fav desk chair. He's followed by BOBBY LEE, 20's, cocksure, wearing a plain khaki uniform and boots.
(to Saunders)
S'cuse me. (to Red)
This here's Bobby Lee. He's a specialist with the Feds. They want him to tag along. Red stares hard at Bobby Lee, then nods.   Bobby Lee step into the Airstream.
Please, Red, ya' gotta' believe me... Red spots Suttle, 35, bright-eyed, with a cowlick, sittin the wheel of the Chevy truck.
Who are you?
Dick Suttle, the driver.
Not anymore.   Bradley. BRADLEY, 35, glasses, moves to the truck and gets in. Suttle shrugs and steps out. Saunders stops Suttle and turns to Red.
This man stays with the vehicle wherever it goes, Red!
(to Suttle)
You know how to operate the gadgets?
Yessir.
(to Suttle)

Grab a seat. Suttle sets himself in the passenger seat of the truck. Sally emerges from the building, ticked off, carrying an armload of file boxes, and makes a beeline for Red. Saunders gently touches Red's shoulders; a final plea.
Please Red, I'm beggin'. I mean, what am I suppose to tell the Governor? Sally arrives but before she can spit out a word...

Tell John that Miss Gerber here checked me out on it. Red whistles and the ENGINE REVS. Red closes the door as motor home pulls away. Saunders runs beside the passenger side window and yells in to Suttle, who stares out the wi
